awd_titl_txt: Standard Grant: Evolving Narratives of Developmental Disabilities in Postwar Clinical Professions
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the 1950s there have been two models of developmental disabilities. The medical models present disability as an undesirable condition, located in an individual body, and in need of treatment or prevention. The social models understand disability as resulting from societal choices and assumptions about how ?normal? humans should interact with their environment. The investigators will examine how social model narratives entered the medical community and influenced professional conceptions and characterizations of developmental disabilities. This project will explore how often-conflicting social and medical perspectives of disability have been bridged in the past, and what can be learned from instances of successful outreach to improve future care. The investigators will present results from this project in medical and disability advocacy forums, and will develop service-learning opportunities for undergraduate students. Undergraduate students will also be involved in archival research for this project, and encouraged to develop their own projects based on these materials. This work will be of interest to genetic counselors, clinical psychologists, pediatric physicians, educators, policy makers and parents.

This project will advance understandings of evolving perspectives on the cause, acceptability, and management of developmental disabilities in the medical community after 1950. The investigators will perform qualitative analysis of archival resources, published literature, and interviews to examine evolving medical community narratives about developmental disabilities, and to determine the extent and scope of hybridization between social and medical model perspectives in various clinical fields. After 1950, many clinicians were exposed to, and some adopted, narratives of developmental disabilities, which focused on unique traits, rather than ?tragic? outcomes. This project will examine how and why new narratives of developmental disabilities entered the medical community, how clinical professionals responded to alternative viewpoints, and the role of some clinicians in promoting the broader adoption of social model perspectives. The investigators will explore how professionals in genetic counseling, clinical psychology, and pediatrics, responded to social model perspectives of developmental disabilities. This project will extend STS frameworks for understanding and analyzing interactions among professional communities with differing levels of power and prestige as they renegotiate longstanding disciplinary categories and approaches to service.

por.por_cntn:
This research examines evolving clinical professional perspectives on disability from the 1950s to the present, with a focus on the fields of clinical psychology, genetic counseling, and pediatrics. The PI explores clinical professionals' responses to more positive and inclusive narratives of disability and describes how various professional considerations and concerns led to many clinical practitioners' resistance to more optimistic and accepting perspectives on disability. Findings demonstrate that disabled clinical professionals can play an important role in encouraging more positive views of disability among their students and patients, as well as professional colleagues, organizations, and academic institutions. The PI strongly encourages clinical professional fields to recruit and support more disabled students and practitioners and examines the history of efforts to do so, since 1960, in various rehabilitation fields.

The PI worked in sixteen archives, examined numerous professional periodicals and textbooks, and conducted 75 oral history interviews with clinical professionals, disabled clinicians and activists, and other advocates. Results from this research have been published in two flagship academic history journals, as well as the American Journal of Public Health and Canadian Medical Association Journal. One more article, to be completed in 2022, will address the history of efforts in rehabilitation professions to increase the prevalence of disabled practitioners in their own fields. In Fall 2022, the PI will publish Disability Dialogues: Advocacy, Science, and Prestige in Postwar Clinical Professions (Johns Hopkins University Press), a book based on the findings of this project.

The products of this research historicize and complicate clinical and scholarly conceptions and uses of the "medical model." The PI demonstrates that the so-called medical model has been used almost exclusively in a pejorative manner, to make an argument about how medicine should be more psychosocially and environmentally-oriented in its approaches to illness and disability. The PI argues that the medical model was never a conscious model of practice for clinicians and that the term was rarely claimed or defended of by clinical professionals. Thus, scholars and activists should be careful not to approach and use the "medical model" as a neutral and purely descriptive term. Rather, the concept has been used rhetorically with various aims. Scholars and disability advocates have often presumed that clinicians resisted more positive and inclusive narratives of disability primarily due to their conscious allegiance to the medical model. Disability Dialogues instead encourages examination of professional concerns, motivations, and pressures that influence clinicians. The PI demonstrates that considerations about professional role, identity, and prestige, along with preferred methodologies and ways of knowing, heavily informed clinicians' often resistant or dismissive responses and interpretations to more optimistic and accepting views of disability.

Disability Dialogues also contributes to historical accounts of sociopolitical activism by biomedical practitioners, by highlighting the voices and activities of disabled clinicians and practitioners with disabled family members in pushing colleagues, students, and professional institutions to reconsider how they conceptualize the abilities and experiences of disabled people. The PI brings attention to the many ways in which disability self-advocates influenced the assumptions and views of clinical professional students and practitioners. Very little other scholarship has addressed the efforts of disabled people to reshape the perspectives and approaches of clinicians toward disability or demonstrated how influential engagement with disabled clinical colleagues can be in disrupting clinicians' pessimistic beliefs about life with disabilities. Disability Dialogues shows that disabled clinicians are uniquely positioned to encourage greater tolerance to, and multiple ways of knowing about, disability among clinical trainees, practitioners, and institutions.

Research and findings from this project have strongly influenced the PI's teaching. The PI has developed a semester long course on the history of disability for undergraduates, as well as a 5-week seminar on the history of disability for medical students. The PI has also integrated major segments on disability into other undergraduate courses. This includes a new course for the 2021-22 academic year, which involves multiple class days on ableism in various scientific and clinical professions. All of these courses and segments have evolved along with the PI's completion of this project, with the addition of new materials, perspectives, and activities drawn from the PI's research.

Work contributing to this research by more than ten undergraduate students was supported by this grant. Students were exposed to various historical and social science theories, trained in oral history and archival methods, and engaged in the synthetic analysis of primary sources related to disability from various clinical disciplines and advocacy groups. Many of these undergraduate research assistants are now in medical school. One has entered a PhD program in the history of science and medicine. These students will bring both methodological skills and more positive and accepting perspectives on disability into their future careers and will be more aware of the viewpoints, challenges, and many successes of disabled clinicians and advocates in their health professional and sociopolitical activist careers.
